threads.com:
This board is for the discussion of classic, or "retro" games, including consoles, computer games, arcade games (including pinball) and any other forms of video games. Retro gaming means platforms launched in 2001 and earlier, and official game titles for those platforms released no later than December 2007 (homebrew console games made after this date will be permitted). The Microsoft Xbox, Nintendo GameCube, Nintendo Game Boy Advance, and Sony PlayStation 2 will now be considered "retro".

Helpful links:
Game Tech Wiki
Emulation General Wiki

threads.com:
The whiplash is pretty intense going from the Super Nintendo to the Nintendo 64. Makes me wish I hadn't gotten so invested in what I would later learn were third party series on the SNES.
>the mega man x series as we know it continued on other gaming platforms excluding the nintendo 64
>the final fantasy series continued on the playstation but not the nintendo 64
>street fighter 2 never got a next generation sequel on the nintendo 64
>games like chrono trigger would get sequels, but not on nintendo consoles
>tried and true nintendo collaborators like konami would launch new IPs while ritually skipping over the nintendo 64
Going from the Super Nintendo to the Nintendo 64 was a pretty sudden feast to famine switch. Even Nintendo seemed to pump to the brakes with popular series like Metroid not appearing on the console at all. Looking back it is much easier to swallow this era as a hiccup in history, but living through it, man it felt like a lifetime. On the other hand, the Gameboy was killing it. Funny how that is.

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.sub: Have you played any TMNT games for the NES?
threads.com:
It's hard to choose a favorite among so many great games, but the first TMNT on the NES is one of the best games the system has to offer.
While it is a game that is quite divisive, I found a lot to love. The difficulty is solid, but it never becomes too hard if you properly utilize the different turtles and sub weapons you can find through exploration. Managing the health of the turtles not only requires you to make risk reward determinations in regards to the best turtle to use in a given situation, but requires you to take note of the pizza locations you have found, and also making determinations on which turtle to give certain subweapons you come across. Much can be said for the imbalance of power in the turtles, Donny being the best, followed by Leo, and then Raph/Mikey. However, this ends up making an interesting psychological impact. This may make someone want to only use Donny and give him the best subweapons, but if you risk always using Donny in overwhelming/quick death situations, you may end up killing Donny and finding yourself only having lackluster turtles for the rest of the level. Similarly, this power imbalance may make an individual want to give the weaker turtles the best subweapons so that all the turtles have strong utility, and losing one turtle never ends up being the end of a run. However, over utilizing the weaker turtles in dangerous situations may end up with you only having Donny for the rest of the round. There are a lot of micro decisions for you to make that impact how you approach the rest of the level/game, and it is these meaningful choices that make this title an extremely interesting Action-Platformer.

>>9441982

> Every PS2 transparent effect or transparent texture is so goddamn smooth

to better point what you said, its that ps2 games utilized an alpha transparency textures (how opaque each pixel is, 0 to 255) and newer "narrow bandwidth" stuff uses alpha masks (to set each pixel as fully transparent or opaque, 0 to 1)

alpha masked textures in foliage generally create a very "aliased" "shimmery" foliage, specially when the camera gets really close.

screen space antialiasing solutions can mitigate that, but lower the image quality in other regards. (FXAA, MLAA)

but modern engines get decent results with TAA or equivalent.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>9443448
American VAs as a profession was sort of an afterthought until the last 15-20 years. VAs were almost entirely used for children's cartoons where a good, serious delivery was basically never needed, with the only other type of "VA" being the kind that read voiceovers for real sports games and announcements where you're conveying a message rather than acting. When Disney started to up their budget for VAs, they instead got actual actors to fill the role or VAs that already had a great reputation, which cost a pretty penny but were absolutely necessary for what they were doing.

Another thing that hurt Japanese devs trying to get American VA is at the time they really didn't have much of an idea what good delivery in the US world was and their American divisions just used the VA budget as a way to keep costs down by hiring cheap actors. It's why US made games on the whole had better VAs than Japanese ones, who couldn't vet the quality of VAs personally due to unfamiliarity with the language.

I don't understand how you can find DQI to be less of a slog than FFI when FFI has more to it, both visually and mechanically.
Since you're playing Origins, I assume you have auto-targeting on. It sounds like a QoL change but I personally found myself bored on auto-pilot when I had it on. Keeping it off makes the fights much more engaging due to the need to keep mental track of enemy HP and optimize actions for efficient combat.
Battles against swarms of enemies go faster when you can use the free spell-casting equipment to immediately thin out the crowd. You start finding this gear about halfway through the game.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>9443395
>I need to start thinking about FF3. What is the "definitive" version of that game? I'm sure it has a bunch of versions just like 1 and 2.
There actually aren't that many since the Famicom version of FF3 never left Japan. For a while most people's experience with FF3 was through the 3D remakes for the DS/PSP/PC. Some people will say the Pixel Remaster is the definite version of the original FF3 as it's an official release of the 2D version (and it has some small QOL changes taken from the 3D port, as well as doing away with the mechanics that penalized you for changing jobs and making the final dungeon a little less punishing). But if you want to experience the original Famicom version there are some translation patches floating around. The 3D remake fleshes out the Onion Kids a little and makes them their own characters to an extent. Though there's some quirk with the battle system because the devs were only able to put 3 enemies on the battle field at once so enemies got a bit buffer to compensate.
Anyway, I'd recommend checking out the 2D version, whether it be the pixel remaster or a translation of the Famicom version.

I'm assuming you meant to say "120V" and no. That's an LM7805 voltage regulator on the board, that means in simple terms it puts out 5V so long as the input voltage is within its specs. last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>9443959
US version was made first and released first, so the JP version benefitted from having all of its issues already pointed out.
This is a recurring trend for Sega games on Saturn and Dreamcast, though there are some individual cases where it's flipped like Jet Grind Radio having less bugs/glitches and a huge amount of additional content that wasn't in Jet Set Radio's original release (and resulted in Jet Set Radio USA coming out afterwards to give Japan the full package).

>What happened to Mad Catz?
The original Madcatz died during the early PS4 generation.

Madcatz went ALL IN on the "rock band" and "guitar hero" controllers. Dumping a ton of resources into making controllers for the game. They bet the entire company on it and thought "instrument controllers" were the future. Then Rock Band 4 did not sell well. Turns out Rock Band was a fad and people were sick of it after Rock Band 3. Madcatz was in deep debt because of their mistake. Mafcatz was broke. The company declared bankruptcy and shut down.


Then a few years later the Chinese bought the Madcatz name. They started making accessories out of a Chinese factory but it's not the same. Not the original Madcatz.

last_replies.com:
>>9442378
>What if you discover an area to cheese a mechanic, would you consider using it as not playing correctly, despite as you said, it would be a strategy you discovered for "less sloppy" execution? How would that be that different then a player figuring out they can take a hit and use invincibility frames to skip a tricky spot?
In game strats are fine. Glitches are fine, but you might want to mention ''I beat the game using the infinite lives glitch'' if it's a major gamebreaking thing.

However, the 1cc thing is a meta-rule, it's not like ingame mechanics or strats, it's more like the assumption that if you say you ''beat the game'' it means you started on the first stage and reached the end credits. If someone says ''I beat the game'' but they only got half way through then dropped it, they are breaking a meta-rule of how we discuss and understand games. They might whine and say we're being arbitrary by going over 50%, but that's too bad for them.

>>9442383
>where does replaying the first mission of Contra Hardcorps factor in when you are trying to figure out a strat for the last level?
If I want to sit down and beat Contra Hardcorps I'm going to do all the levels I have to, since they are all part of the game.
I'm not going to just do the last level and claim I beat it today because I ran the other levels successfully with save states in the past lol

The satisfaction you get from beating the whole game, legit, start to finish is much more than doing segmented runs with save states or spamming continues because it's far more challenging and requires much more thought, and far more precise execution.

>>9443118
Konami was lawsuit happy around Tokimeki Memorial (1996-1997) to protect its image and this included not only porn, but cheat devices and PS1 memory cards with preinstalled saves (some companies later did their own preinstalled save stuff officially for promotional stuff). They won.

Nintendo sued some doujinshi in 1998 but relented for some uncharacteristic reason because of backlash within the industry.

Some third rate nip developer was really irate around 2003 because some blog trashed his game while using screenshots of the game, so he said those screenshots are copyright infringement. He actually won. Japan has no fair use clause, one of the episodes of the Osomatsu-Kun and Gintama animes were not reissued on DVDs over this.

MMOs happened in the late nineties and players were complaining about cheaters. Anti-cheat solutions that were robust existed, they would check for memory state constantly and connected peripherals and have all sorts of failsafe checks, YET you only see them in games where money is involved. There's an American NES game with a bonus level yet to be cracked to this day, because a massive money prize was on the line, and it had all kinds of checks against the Game Genie. There are horse betting peripherals for the Famicom and Super Famicom (that even got a location test in the United States by Nintendo, then still doing casino-themed games. They only really stopped when they cancelled a DS game after PEGI made the themes an automatic +18 rating) that have massive protection.

When companies started to experiment with virtual markets for selling prizes, expansion content already on disc, selling what was previously bonus official cheats and extras as DLC, microtransactions that rely on making the game as hostile to you as possible, heavier protections were put into place and eventually everything was sandboxed, and companies specialized in providing anti-cheat solutions.

Cheats from PSP/3DS on are doable via custom firmware apps.

Kind of individual leveling for the PSP version (also fixes the "new class drops to level 1" problem), a cheat from one of /vrpg/ threads:

_C0 Individual Unit Levels
_L 0x2000E690 0x34050000 # do not downlevel on world map
_L 0x2000F038 0x9285004A # do not downlevel ally after recruitment (Canopus)
_L 0x2000FF94 0x00000000 # fake Guest everyone after battle
_L 0x200460AC 0x92C5004A # do not downlevel enemy after recruitment
_L 0x200BF1A8 0x9205004A # generate join offer stats based on in-battle Lv. (Donnalto)
_L 0x200BF260 0x00000000 # keep innate unit Lv in join offer of non-combatants (Sara, Voltare)
_L 0x200FF9AC 0x9245004A # keep unit Lv. during reclassing 1/2
_L 0x200FFBB4 0x9226024E # keep unit Lv. during reclassing 2/2
_L 0x20127460 0x9205004A # no "Unit's level changed." prompt
_L 0x20127588 0x9205004A # equipment remains equipped if unit's Lv. is high enough
>However, units will not level up until the level of their class matches their unit level.
>For example, you recruit your first gryphon at Lv.4 and it will remain at Lv.4 (instead of dropping to Lv.1) until gryphon's class level reaches 5. This is how the game treats guest units and I'm faking everyone as a guest (for level-checking purposes only) in the cheat above.

This but implemented properly + QoL fixes + toning down the grind and a little rebalance is all they had to do to the PSP version to make it finally good. >>9439483
>Why did Konami and Capcom make so many licensed games based on western cartoons
Because they had existing engines and assets, and why not reuse them cheaply for an extra assured buck with established franchises?
Heavy asset reuse from Street Fighter and Mega Man X resulted in most of Capcom's Disney output on SNES (and Darkwing Duck is a heavily modified Mega Man 3 plus a shield, most of the staff worked on it), similar to Konami and their beat-em-ups and platformer (Goemon, Castlevania) games, and IntiCreates reusing Mega Man Zero engine and assets for a shit ton of JP-only Shin-Chan/Keroro Gunso games and other obscure anime.

Nintendo, Namco, and Bandai's situation was different, they were publishers. Their anime output didn't have consistent quality, and each time it was a new developer and a new project, not necessarily building off an existing project with a solid foundation. Namco Bandai's dynamics changed quite a bit with Namco and Branpesto getting absorbed and them relying less on external devs.

Sega, Natsume, Enix overproduced their anime games. High quality but not sustainable.

TOSE were uncredited codemonkeys. While talented and competent when explicitly left to their own devices for game design roles as well (Starfy/Rocket Slime series) or given strong direction and good game specs (Zelda Breath of the Wild Switch, and multiple major Nintendo EAD projects before + there's an Activision NES dev who was impressed they put EVERYTHING he asked for in an overambitious spec sheet full of designer wankery, and it worked WELL), they were really not encouraged to have a strong creative voice, just implement what the game designers and artists and project director wants and ship the game without lawsuits over contracted code like with Ikegami's Donkey Kong or needless creative differences. That's what makes developers use their services and outsource to them. If they work on shitty games, it's more often than not the main developer's fault.

last_replies.name: Anonymous

>>9440698
>I just can’t get over how empty 1 feels. Every level in 2 is more memorable because the characters in it have a story and a goal.
All that's telling me is you prefer NPCs over core gameplay. But here's the rub: NPCs are themselves boring. They're one note characters that make you do a basic bitch minigame for five minutes before you fuck off. Spyro 1 has better core gameplay. More exciting jumps, better use of momentum physics, more interesting level designs. Spyro 2/3 diluted the core gameplay until there was almost nothing left but basic platforms that served little but to be a vehicle for questgivers. That's why Insomniac ran into a wall. They went the wrong direction for expanding the gameplay, adding in a bunch of minigames and gimmicks instead of focusing on the core gameplay. When they ran out of gimmicks to add, they stopped working on Spyro. Ratchet and Clank suffers this issue a little bit as well, though the shooting mechanics help take your mind off of it. After Spyro 1 Insomniac really felt like they didn't want to make platformers at all, they only continued due to historical reasons. It's not shocking they ditched the genre entirely down the road.

>and got a complete overhaul based on the dreamcast port

The Dreamcast version was suppose to come with BlueShift as a Dreamcast exclusive. But, Gearbox made it a stand-alone expansion for the PC instead. It also came bundled with Opposing Forces, and the HD model pack. The HD models were based on the ones that Gearbox made for the Dreamcast game. One of the improvements that the Dreamcast port was adverting were it's higher polygon models for 'security guards', 'scientists', enemies, gun models, etc. Back then, there was no option to enable the HD models in game for HL1, if you owned Blue-Shift. Valve's help page lead to an external link to download them separately. But then, when Half-Life added Linux and Mac support, and OpenGL (again), they also added the toggle switch for HD content. Way back in the day, if you registered a Half-Life 1 CD key with Valve, give you both expansion packs, as well as other GoldSRC engines games not called Counter-Strike to your library, as a complementary thing. image taken from my account history.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>9440378
The audience for old system JRPGs does exist but I doubt it is large. Approach it as a labor of love side project or a learning experience but not as a means of significant income.
>but with more modern story telling.
What does this mean?
>I would focus more on the story
The story is the part I care about least in a JRPG.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
The problem is exactly that there were too many of those projects, too many programs designed so anyone can make his own RPG, which lead to a pile of mediocre stuff so noone is interested in this anymore.

So you'd really have to make something that stands out or already be someon.

The other issue is that RPGs have for long turned into something for which what matters the most are story and graphics. This can be said for many genres, but more so for RPGs. And the entire point of making an oldschool Famicom style RPG would be an emphasis on gameplay, something the RPG audience does not care for anymore.

I too have a bunch of ideas for a Famicom RPG, and I already am a retro game designer with a foot in the industry, but I doubt I will ever fullfill this RPG idea because it is too risky. But if I had to do it, I would make sure not to use any of the shit "do it yourself" programs peoplel are recommending you, make sure to hire a visual artist that stands out, but only after a market research that tells me if and how I can release it in Japan.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com: If you want "modern storytelling" in a JRPG, google "top earthbound clones". You'll find no shortage of bearded genx postmodernists trying to express the ennui of their existence through overly cute sprites and kitschy ironic Americana.
